t: Psalm 49
To the chief Musician, A Psalm for the sons of Korah.
Hear*p this, all ye people; give ear, all ye inhabitants of the world:
Both*p low and high, rich and poor, together.
My*p mouth shall speak of wisdom; and the meditation of my heart shall be of understanding.
I*p will incline mine ear to a parable: I will open my dark saying upon the harp.
Wherefore*p should I fear in the days of evil, when the iniquity of my heels shall compass me about?
They*p that trust in their wealth, and boast themselves in the multitude of their riches;
None*p of them can by any means redeem his brother, nor give to God a ransom for him:
(For*p the redemption of their soul is precious, and it ceaseth for ever:)
That*p he should still live for ever, and not see corruption.
For*p he seeth that wise men die, likewise the fool and the brutish person perish, and leave their wealth to others.
Their*p inward thought is, that their houses shall continue for ever, and their dwelling places to all generations; they call their lands after their own names.
Nevertheless*p man being in honour abideth not: he is like the beasts that perish.
This*p their way is their folly: yet their posterity approve their sayings. Selah.
Like*p sheep they are laid in the grave; death shall feed on them; and the upright shall have dominion over them in the morning; and their beauty shall consume in the grave from their dwelling.
But*p God will redeem my soul from the power of the grave: for he shall receive me. Selah.
Be*p not thou afraid when one is made rich, when the glory of his house is increased;
For*p when he dieth he shall carry nothing away: his glory shall not descend after him.
Though*p while he lived he blessed his soul: and men will praise thee, when thou doest well to thyself.
He*p shall go to the generation of his fathers; they shall never see light.
Man*p that is in honour, and understandeth not, is like the beasts that perish.
